bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Florence M. Read, November 23, 1923

div1.p: Carter writes to Read that he believes the West African case was not yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Florence M. Read, November 23, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
------ F. F. Russell.
Africa
(Garuba case)
-----------
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
November 23, 1923.
Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of Nov. 19th. in reference to the case
of Mr. Garuba. I would say that the clinical history (D. Fitzgerald
Moore) suggests to me that the diagnosis is either yellow fever: acute
yellow atrophy of the liver or Weil's disease. “The lips being covered
with large sores” suggests herpes labialis--common in Weil's disease
and of only accidental occurrence in yellow fever.

The fact that there was no vomiting, although the man was not
in coma (“extremely restless”) during the last 15 1/2 hours of his life
is also unusual in yellow fever.

The clinical history, however, covers only the 16 1/2 hours pre-
ceeding death and is less illuminating than if it had covered the
whole period of illness.

For the autopsy: the fact that the urine was “intensely dark”
is decidedly against the diagnosis of yellow fever as is the fact
that “albumen” was “present in” only “moderate quantity” in a dying
case.

The slight amount of fatty tissue in liver and kidneys would al-
so not be expected in the case of a man dying at the end of five days
days
2
of yellow fever. The enlarged and congested spleen: the large amount of
necrosis of liver tissue, with extremely little fat showing: the fact that
the glomeruli of the kidneys seemed to be affected while the tubular epi-
thilium (usually bearing the stress of the yellow fever attack) were only
slightly swollen --they are not mentioned as being fatty or having disap-
peared-- is also extremely against the diagnosis of yellow fever.

The points noted, while not sufficient maybe to negative the diagnosis of
yellow fever, to me render it highly improbable.
